prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Types of actions transferred—Types of cases in which transfer is denied

para.paratext: There really aren't any types of cases that arise before the Panel repeatedly enough to declare a trend and in which the Panel has shown a tendency to deny transfer. However, certain types of actions, for example, patent actions, frequently involve only a few cases and are therefore less likely to be transferred than others. Other factors militating against transfer may also correlate with the type of case, but type of case itself is never determinative of the transfer question. Cases may meet the statutory prerequisites to transfer, but simply not “share sufficient common questions of fact to warrant” transfer.[1] Although this conclusion is more likely in a small group of diverse actions, even a large number of actions may simply not warrant centralization.[2]

The Panel frequently denies transfer with the cryptic statement that alternatives to transfer exist.[3] This is certainly more likely to occur when other factors that don't favor transfer are present—notably a small number of actions,[4] but can happen when there are numerous actions[5] or in other circumstances. Generally, the Panel probably views coordination between the courts in which the actions are pending as providing a sufficient means for managing the litigation. These coordination tools are discussed in the Manual for Complex Litigation.[6] Although the presence of meaningful alternatives to transfer may be persuasive in the Panel's decision-making, it is an argument that is difficult for the parties to advance. It is tried often by parties seeking to avoid the very efficiencies multidistrict transfer is intended to foster, and the Panel has frequently rejected these arguments.[7]

A party seeking to avoid centralization based on the alternative of voluntary, informal coordination should attempt to present detailed evidence that would support a conclusion that that cooperation is likely to have the desired benefits. Obtaining the agreement to work collaboratively in advance of the Panel hearing may be persuasive to the Panel.[8] Even better than an expression of willingness to cooperate prospectively is a demonstration that the parties have been succeeding in the efforts to deal with the litigation issues collaboratively.[9] Cooperation of the judges presiding in case in different districts can also be persuasive to the Panel.[10] Similarly, if the Panel views the voluntary efforts at informal coordination as not being successful to date, it is likely to discount this argument.[11]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

In re Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Patent Litigation, 395 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Midpoint Development, LLC, Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 2d 1353, 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2004). See also In re Boeing Co. Employment Practices Litigation (No. II), 293 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
See, e.g., In re Not-For-Profit Hospitals/Uninsured Patients Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (transfer denied even though 28 actions pending).

See, e.g., In re Depo-Provera Products Liability Litigation, 499 F. Supp. 2d 1348 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Orthopaedic Implant Device Antitrust Litigation, 483 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re Helicopter Crash Near Zachary, Louisiana, on Dec. 9, 2004, 484 F. Supp. 2d 1354 (J.P.M.L. 2007); In re New Century Mortg. Corp. Prescreening Litigation, 473 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Highway Accident in Buffalo County, Nebraska, 305 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Sprint Corp. PCS Network Contract Litigation, 303 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Boeing Co. Employment Practices Litigation (No. II), 293 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Georgeson Shareholder Communications, Inc., Share Exchange Litigation, 277 F. Supp. 2d 1372 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Equicredit Corp. Mortg. Lending Practices Litigation, 276 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Advantage Investors Mortg. Corp. Mortg. Funds Litigation, 268 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Personalized Media Communications, L.L.C., 261 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re AT & T Broadband Telecommunication Services Litigation, 237 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Zimmer, Inc., 237 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Unitrin, Inc., Ins. Sales Practices Litigation, 217 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re American General Finance, Inc., 217 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re DaimlerChrysler Corp. Seat Belt Buckle Products Liability Lit., 217 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Pharmacy Ben. Plan Administrators Pricing Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1362 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re W.E. Hall Co., Patent Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Fleet Bank Credit Card Terms Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Lawrence Moore/International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Litigation, 198 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Monochloroacetic Acid (MCAA) Antitrust Litigation, 187 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2002); In re Chromated Copper Arsenate (CCA) Treated Wood Products Liability Litigation, 188 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2002).

See, e.g., In re Highway Accident in Buffalo County, Nebraska, 305 F. Supp. 2d 1359 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (3 actions in 2 districts); In re Boeing Co. Employment Practices Litigation (No. II), 293 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2003) (3 actions, minimal common issues); In re Advantage Investors Mortg. Corp. Mortg. Funds Litigation, 268 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003) (2 actions); In re Personalized Media Communications, L.L.C., 261 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2003) (2 actions); In re AT & T Broadband Telecommunication Services Litigation, 237 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (same); In re W.E. Hall Co., Inc., Patent Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1367 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (same); In re Fleet Bank Credit Card Terms Litigation, 206 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (same); In re Lawrence Moore/International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Litigation, 198 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (same).
In re American General Finance, Inc., 217 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2002) (transfer denied despite presence of 22 actions).

See Manual for Complex Litigation Fourth § 20.14 (2004); see generally David F. Herr, Annotated Manual for Complex Litigation Fourth (West 2018). The Panel has specifically cited to this section in one case where it denied transfer in a docket involving 6 actions. See In re Soc. of Lloyd's Judgment Enforcement Litigation, 321 F. Supp. 2d 1381, 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2004). The portions of the Manual dealing explicitly with multidistrict litigation are included in this book as Appendix E.
The cases in which the Panel has expressed rejection of this argument are collected in § 5:51, below.

See In re Credit Suisse VelocityShares Daily Inverse VIX Short Term Exchange Traded Notes Securities Litigation, 326 F. Supp. 3d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018); In re Blue Spike, LLC, Patent Litigation, 278 F. Supp. 3d 1379 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017) (Panel points to defendants’ filing of joint brief and agreement joint deposition of inventor); In re Xytex Corporation Sperm Donor Products Liability Litigation, 223 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016).
See, e.g., In re Brazilian Prosthetic Device Bribery Litigation, 283 F. Supp. 3d 1381 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).

See In re Express Scripts Holding Company Securities, Derivative and Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) Litigation, 273 F. Supp. 3d 1369 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017) (coordination in 3 of 4 pending actions).

See In re Sorin 3T Heater-Cooler System Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 289 F. Supp. 3d 1335 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2018) (informal coordination isn't working); In re Eliquis (Apixaban) Products Liability Litigation, 282 F. Supp. 3d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017).
